edu.iastate.cs228.hw1

Class Property

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.iastate.cs228.hw1.Property

  • public class Property
extends java.lang.Object
    Author:
    Yuxiang Chen This class maintains properties obtained from reading a configuration file. For methods that require copying values of a String array, you may write your own private method to do the copy or use the generic method public static T[] Arrays.copyOf(T[] original, int newLength) E.g., String[] oldArray={"1","2","3"}; String[] newArray=null; newArray = Arrays.copyOf(oldArray, oldArray.length);

    • Constructor Detail

      • Property

        public Property()
        Default constructor Set the default values of all member variables. By default, the array of positive terms has "fun", "happy", "positive". By default, the array of negative terms has "sad", "bad", "angry". By default, the array of stop terms keeps "a", "an", "the". The default value of the scoring method is 0. The default value of the minimum distance is 0.5.

      • Property

        public Property(Property p)
        Copy constructor; deep copy Copy all the values of the member variables of the input Property object to this object.
        Parameters:
        p - Property object as input

      • Property

        public Property(java.lang.String configFileName)
        Initialize member variables with values read from the given configuration file. The content of the file is case sensitive. Set all the properties to the default values first. Read the configuration file and overrides the default properties if the values in the configuration file are valid. See the example of the configuration file in the assignment description. We assume that users do not provide duplicated terms for positive terms, negative terms, or stop terms. You do not need to check whether positive terms, negative terms, or stop terms overlap. You do not need to check duplicates within each array of terms. Ignore any properties that do not match the above predefined properties. Use try catch to handle IOException or NumberFormatException. If any of them occurs, print on the screen to indicate such an error and use the default values for all the properties like those set in the default constructor. You do not need to handle other exceptions. Properly close the file when done. You may introduce your own private method to keep the code concise. No JUnit is needed for these private methods.
        Parameters:
        configFileName - Name of the configuration file
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if configFileName is null

    • Method Detail

      • getPositiveTerms

        public java.lang.String[] getPositiveTerms()
        Returns:
        A copy of the array of positive terms. May return an empty String array if the orginal array is empty.

      • setPositiveTerms

        public void setPositiveTerms(java.lang.String[] newTerms)
        Set the content of the positiveTerms array to the content of the newTerms array. Both arrays must have the same length and the same content once this method returns. Make sure that positiveTerms and newTerms do not reference the same array object since we do not want the positiveTerm Property to change unknowingly because the content of newTerms are changed.
        Parameters:
        newTerms - Array of String of new words to use as positive terms
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - when newTerms is null or the array is empty

      • getNegativeTerms

        public java.lang.String[] getNegativeTerms()
        Returns:
        A copy of the array of negative terms. May return an empty String array if the orginal array is empty.

      • setNegativeTerms

        public void setNegativeTerms(java.lang.String[] newTerms)
        Set the content of the negativeTerms array to the content of the newTerms array. Both arrays must have the same length and the same content once this method returns. Make sure that negativeTerms and newTerms do not reference the same array object since we do not want the negative terms of this Property object to change unknowingly because newTerms are changed.
        Parameters:
        newTerms - Array of String of new words to use as negative terms
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - when newTerms is null or the array is empty

      • getStopTerms

        public java.lang.String[] getStopTerms()
        Returns:
        A copy of the array of stop terms May return an empty array if the orginal array is empty.

      • setStopTerms

        public void setStopTerms(java.lang.String[] newTerms)
        Set the content of the stopTerms array to the content of the newTerms array. Both arrays must have the same length and the same content once this method returns. Make sure that stopTerms and newTerms do not reference the same array object since we do not want the stop terms of this Property object to change unknowingly because newTerms are changed.
        Parameters:
        newTerms - Array of String of new words to use as stop terms
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - when newTerms is null or the array is empty

        Throws:

      • getMinDistance

        public double getMinDistance()
        Returns:
        Value of the member variable keeping the minimum distance for sentiment classification

      • setMinDistance

        public void setMinDistance(double newdistance)
        Set the value of the member variable that keeps the minimum distance to the value of newdistance.
        Parameters:
        newdistance - New minimum distance
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - when the newdistance is not positive.

      • equals

        public boolean equals(java.lang.Object o)
        Two objects are equals if they have same values for all their private member variables: positiveTerms, negativeTerms, stopTerms, scoringMethod, and minDistance. Implement the method using the guidelines given in class. For comparing two arrays, make sure that the content of the two arrays at the same index have the same value and the two arrays have the same length. You may write your own private method to compare or you may use Arrays.equals() or Arrays.deepEquals() for this purpose. These two methods return different results for nested arrays. For comparing doubles, two doubles are equal if they differ less than a small error range, defined as 0.000001 here.
        Overrides:
        equals in class java.lang.Object
